titleStmt.title: The Dying Veteran
a hand-written transcription

availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: A dated, signed draft of "The Dying Veteran," first published in 1887. A note at end reads: "Given to Thomas Mosher by Horace Traubel, 1904." On verso of the page is a note by Whitman to "Mr. Curtz" (type setter) asking for a finished proof by the middle of the afternoon, Wednesday.

lg.head: The Dying Veteran
lg.note: [A Long Island incident, early part of the present century.]
lg.l: Amid the days of order, ease, ease, prosperity,
Amid the ‸current songs of beauty, peace, decorum,
I cast a reminiscence—(likely 'twill offend you,

I knewheard it in my boyhood)—More than a gen⹀
erationgeneration
since,

From Revolutionary times aA queerA queer old savage man,
a fighter under Washington himself,

Large, brave, cleanly, hot⹀blooded, no talker, rather
spiritualistic,

(‸Had Fought in the ranks—fought well—had been all
through the ‸rRevolutionary war,)

Lay dying—sons, daughters, church⹀deacons lovingly
tending him

Sharping their sense, their ears, toward his
‸murmuring‸rambling, half⹀caught words:
"Let me return again to my war⹀days,
Body and soul to my war⹀days,
To ‸the sights and scenes—‸—to forming the line of battle,
To the cannons, the grim artillery
To the galloping and carrying orders,
The wounded, the fallen, the heat, the suspense
The perfume strong, the smoke, the deafening noise.
Away with your life of peace!—your joys of peace!
Give me themy old wild battle⹀joyslife again!"

body.note: Given to Thomas Mosher by Horace Traubel 1904
